channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: 'It's horrible': Air traffic controllers under mounting pressure as shutdown drags on
item.description: Air traffic controllers are finding it increasingly difficult to keep doing their jobs without getting a paycheck during the government shutdown. Some are starting to speak out.
item.content:encoded: Air traffic controllers are finding it increasingly difficult to keep doing their jobs without getting a paycheck during the government shutdown. Some are starting to speak out.
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: Union president talks about judge's ruling halting shutdown layoffs
item.description: Everett Kelley, the president of the American Federation of Government Employees, talks about a judge's ruling stopping the Trump administration from firing federal worker during the shutdown.
item.content:encoded: Everett Kelley, the president of the American Federation of Government Employees, talks about a judge's ruling stopping the Trump administration from firing federal worker during the shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: Democratic leaders sue Trump administration for stopping food aid during the shutdown
item.description: Democratic leaders are suing the Trump administration for ending food aid programs during the shutdown. They argue, despite the administration's claims, there are emergency funds available.
item.content:encoded: Democratic leaders are suing the Trump administration for ending food aid programs during the shutdown. They argue, despite the administration's claims, there are emergency funds available.
item.dc:creator: Sylvia Goodman

item.title: The Fed is expected to cut interest rates as job market shows signs of weakness
item.description: The Federal Reserve is expected to cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter percentage point because the central bank is more concerned about the job market than it is with battling inflation.
item.content:encoded:
The Federal Reserve is expected to cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter percentage point because the central bank is more concerned about the job market than it is with battling inflation.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in eastern Cuba, Israel orders strikes on Gaza weeks into the ceasefire, Air traffic controllers face mounting pressure as they work without pay during the shutdown.
item.content:encoded: Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in eastern Cuba, Israel orders strikes on Gaza weeks into the ceasefire, Air traffic controllers face mounting pressure as they work without pay during the shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: 'Expensive Basketball' highlights some of the game's legendary players and moments
item.description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with author Shea Serrano about his new book, "Expensive Basketball," an examination of some of the game's most iconic players and moments.
item.content:encoded: NPR's A Martinez speaks with author Shea Serrano about his new book, "Expensive Basketball," an examination of some of the game's most iconic players and moments.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez

item.title: El Fasher falls to RSF as Sudan army loses final Darfur stronghold
item.description: Sudan's Rapid Support Forces took control of El Fasher, leaving hundreds of thousands of residents trapped under RSF control and at risk of being killed.
item.content:encoded: Sudan's Rapid Support Forces took control of El Fasher, leaving hundreds of thousands of residents trapped under RSF control and at risk of being killed.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu

item.title: Sudanese-American poet talks about the fall of her hometown El Fasher
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Sudanese-American poet Emi Mahmoud about the fall of Al-Fashir to the Rapid Support Forces in Sudan.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Sudanese-American poet Emi Mahmoud about the fall of Al-Fashir to the Rapid Support Forces in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: Iowa has an OB-GYN shortage. Some doctors blame the state's strict abortion ban
item.description: Iowa ranks last among states for the number of OB-GYNS per capita. State legislators are trying to recruit more, but some doctors say the state's strict abortion ban is partially to blame.
item.content:encoded: Iowa ranks last among states for the number of OB-GYNS per capita. State legislators are trying to recruit more, but some doctors say the state's strict abortion ban is partially to blame.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Krebs

item.title: Hurricane Melissa strikes eastern Cuba after devastating Jamaica
item.description: Hurricane Melissa, one of the strongest Atlantic storms on record, made landfall for the second time in 14 hours, striking Cuba Wednesday after unleashing powerful winds and flooding across Jamaica.
item.content:encoded: Hurricane Melissa, one of the strongest Atlantic storms on record, made landfall for the second time in 14 hours, striking Cuba Wednesday after unleashing powerful winds and flooding across Jamaica.
item.dc:creator: Eyder Peralta
